raw_comment: I notice that people with legacy have more admitted than those without it, even though their income might be less. Legacy students have a higher income rate than non legacy and than even the richest applicants. I also noticed the richest students who are also legacy applicants are most likely to be accepted. I wonder why the poorest students who are legacy seem to still have a good acceptance rate because you would expect them not to. I also wonder why the legacy students have an advantage regardless of other factors. It impacts me and my community because it is not long before I begin the college application process and these statistics and this information is becoming more relevant to me each year. I would title this graph "Leading with Legacy"
ace_sentences: I notice that applicants with legacy status are admitted more often than applicants without legacy status.
This happens even if the income of an applicant with legacy status is lower than the income of an applicant without legacy status.
Legacy students have a higher income rate than non-legacy students.
Legacy students have a higher income rate than the richest applicants.
The richest students who are legacy applicants are most likely to be accepted.
I wonder why the poorest students who are legacy students still have a good acceptance rate.
A person can expect that the poorest students who are legacy students do not have a good acceptance rate.
I wonder why legacy students have an advantage regardless of other factors.
I will begin the college application process soon.
These statistics become more relevant to me each year.
The title of this graph is "Leading with Legacy".
